chapter.title: Attack Shield
chapter.para:
The Attack Shield is identified by the
symbol. If the Attack Shield Appliance is not installed, please refer to for installation instructions.
The Attack Shield Appliance protects your network in two ways. It sanitizes all packets the ⪚ receives. This packet-cleaning is a built-in function and has no administrative settings.
In addition to protecting against lower-level networking attacks, the Attack Shield also protects against Denial of Service (DOS) attacks. This feature is explained in more detail in .

sect1.title: Denial Of Service Protection
sect1.para: The Attack Shield Appliance keeps tracks traffic from all hosts (IP addresses). The number of connections and the volume of data are monitored. If a given host is significantly more active than others, its reputation increases. Reputation is expressed as a number on a relative scale. Large reputation numbers indicate that a given host is consuming more resources (more connections, more bytes transferred) than its peers.

As the load on an ⪚ increases, it will not have enough resources to service all requests. Rather than slow everyone down, the Attack Shield Appliance takes action against those hosts with the largest reputation numbers. In this way, hosts that hog all the bandwidth are allocated fewer resources while normal clients see no change in service and performance levels. There are three actions that the Attack Shield Appliance can take against hosts with large reputation numbers, enumerated in .

listitem.para: Limited - When the Attack Shield Appliance limits a host's access to resources inside the protected networks. The limited host experiences a mild slowdown in network performance.
Dropped - When the Attack Shield Appliance causes a host's traffic to be dropped, it has the effect of slowing-down traffic greater than if the traffic was simply limited.
Rejected - When the Attack Shield Appliance rejects a host's traffic, the host is temporarily prevented from accessing the protected networks through the ⪚.

sect1.para: By using reputation numbers to allocate resources, the Attack Shield Appliance protects a network from Denial of Service attacks. When a host attempts to flood a network protected by the ⪚, the attacking host's reputation number quickly increases so that the host moves from experiencing a limited slowdown to being denied access to protected resources.

sect1.title: Administrative Interface
sect1.para: The Attack Shield Appliance does not have any settings for sanitizing packets, but does have a setting to specify a host that is treated differently than its peers in terms of reputation calculation. This administrative setting is explained in . The Event Log tab, explained in , allows administrators to view events (see for general information about ⪚ Event Logs).

sect2.title: Exception List
sect2.para: The Exception List of the Attack Shield Appliance is shown in .

The Exception List is used to identify a virtual host (IP Address) that represents more than one physical machine. As discussed in the Attack Shield Appliance tracks the relative activity of hosts on its network. If a given address represents more than one physical machine (for example, with NAT), then the Attack Shield Appliance must know this or it will consider the NATed network to be an unusually active single host.

To add a new entry to the Exception List, push the add (plus) button to the left of the table. All fields and their meaning for adding/modifying exception entries is as follows.
enable
When this box is checked, the exception rule is enabled.
address
The IP Address of the host that will receive special consideration.
user count
The number of users (machines) that this address should be considered to represent. For example, if 5 users are behind a NAT system, the external IP address of that NAT system should receive a user count of 5.
category
A category for the entry. This is for administrative reference only.
description
A description of the entry. This is for administrative reference only.

sect2.title: Event Log
sect2.para: The Events tab contents is shown in .

The Events Tab is another implementation of an Event Log, as described in . The complete list of columns and their meaning is as follows.
Events Tab
timestamp
The time the event took place
source
The source IP address of the traffic.
source interface
The network interface on-which the traffic arrived at the ⪚. For more information on the network interfaces of your ⪚, please refer to .
reputation
As described in , the reputation is a relative value assigned to clients to indicate their consumption of network resources. This value is usually between 0 and 100, with larger numbers indicating greater resource consumption.
limited
The number of times the source client was limited (in a period of time) corresponding to the event. For a review of what it means for clients to be limited, please refer to .
dropped
The number of times the source client was had traffic dropped (in a period of time) corresponding to the event. For a review of what it means for clients to have traffic dropped, please refer to .
reject
The number of times the source client had traffic rejected (in a period of time) corresponding to the event. For a review of what it means for clients to have traffic dropped, please refer to .
